posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked:
I’m working on some new additions to my design calculator , including a motor curve generator. It’s not quite ready to go live yet, but with the announcement of the new brushless motor options for 2024 I wanted to show the comparison between them.

I am limiting these plots at 80 Amps in order to focus on the section of the curves that is relevant for FRC. Slightly different from what you may have seen previously, these curves have the motor torque on the x-axis instead of the speed. This is done because, in general in FRC, we have a fixed load torque and modulate the motor speed by changing the voltage, rather than having a fixed voltage and modulating the speed by changing the load. So in these graphs, higher load i.e. slower speed is on the right, and lower load i.e. higher speed is on the left.

Motor Curve Display - AMB Robotics Calculator 1183×2346 200 KB

Motor Curve Display - AMB Robotics Calculator 1183×2346 200 KB

Motor Curve Display - AMB Robotics Calculator 1183×2346 200 KB

We can see a few interesting things here. The Kraken has the highest power at 80A, followed closely by the Falcon and then the NEO Vortex, with the original NEO falling well behind. The motor efficiencies at 80A are in the same order. However, at lower torques (e.g. a flywheel), the order is reversed, with the original NEO being significantly more efficient than the rest.

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: How have you handled having different testing methodologies between REV, WCP, and VEX? Who’s data did you use for the NEO 1.1 and Falcon? Also, how would this change if you geared these all for the same RPM?

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked:
Another way to look at the same data is gearing all of the motors to produce the same torque at 80A and comparing their speed/power/efficiency. Since all motors are drawing 80A @ 12V, their input powers are all the same 960W. And since they’re all outputting the same 1.45 Nm of torque, their output power, and therefore efficiency as well, is only dependent on the motor’s speed.

Motor Curve Display - AMB Robotics Calculator (1) 1183×2346 202 KB

Motor Curve Display - AMB Robotics Calculator (1) 1183×2346 202 KB

Motor Curve Display - AMB Robotics Calculator (1) 1183×2346 202 KB

Here we can clearly see: the Kraken has the highest speed (i.e. most power), followed by the Falcon, NEO Vortex, and original NEO, in that order.

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked:
Eliot Dunn:

How have you handled having different testing methodologies between REV, WCP , and VEX? Who’s data did you use for the NEO 1.1 and Falcon?

I’m using the data provided by each manufacturer. I haven’t seen a conclusive reason to doubt any of those numbers.

Eliot Dunn:

Also, how would this change if you geared these all for the same RPM ?

That’s another way to analyze the same data.

Motor Curve Display - AMB Robotics Calculator 1183×2346 204 KB

Motor Curve Display - AMB Robotics Calculator 1183×2346 204 KB

The results are the same in terms of power at 80A.

posts.name: kgzak
posts.cooked:
The reason to doubt is that the falcon on the same dyno (according to rev) has less peak power than the cyclone.

640watts for cyclone and 588 for falcon.

669.12 KB

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked:
True, but VEX also claims that the original NEO has less power than REV reports when measured on their dyno.

https://motors.vex.com/other-motors/neo

Until there are measurements from a neutral source, I’ll stick with the manufacturer reported specs. When the new calculator goes live, you’ll be able to input custom motor specs so you can decide for yourself who to trust.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked:
kgzak:

640watts for cyclone and 588 for falcon.

Just for clarity sake, are you reffering to the new REV Vortex motor here when you say cyclone? Given the numbers you’ve listed, I think you are, but want to be sure.

posts.name: kgzak
posts.cooked:
On that page rev states 456 watts to vex’s 516.

Rev has lower values for every motor compared to vex, they state they are using a different methodology so that is likely the reason for it. Based on the numbers I see from all manufacturers I would guess peak power numbers would be Neo<falcon<vortex<kraken. If we can budget it, we might try to do some side by side comparisons of the two motors.

posts.name: kgzak
posts.cooked: Yes. Don’t know why I have been calling it that.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
Please don’t mix data from different dynos! REV makes note of this on their tests. You can see that their Falcon (non-FOC) data is way lower than the Vex numbers. Without knowing how the dyno test is done, comparing across different manufacturers is not a good idea.

If you release this calculator, please wait for manufactures to at least publish cross-motor numbers so that you can upscale/downscale the numbers appropriately.

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked:
For good measure, I replaced the NEO specs with those measured by VEX (so all of the motors except the Vortex and Kraken are measured on the same dyno). Dark blue is still the NEO even though it says “custom”.

Motor Curve Display - AMB Robotics Calculator 1183×2346 202 KB

Motor Curve Display - AMB Robotics Calculator 1183×2346 202 KB

Motor Curve Display - AMB Robotics Calculator 1183×2346 202 KB

The output power at 80A is still the same order, though the NEO is not as significantly below the rest. Its efficiency at low torques is now much lower than before, near the bottom of the list. I imagine the Vortex would perform better if it also used testing data from Vex’s dyno, but we won’t know for sure until they test it and publish the data (if they ever do).

posts.name: Anand Rajamani

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked: True, I edited that in my post. But until we have a single source measuring all of the motors, this will have to do.
